script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, I've been pondering something intriguing about how these chapters begin. The Bible opens with 'in the beginning God created the heaven and the earth,' but Moses chapter 1 starts in a completely different place. Why do you think the Lord gave us that vision first?

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's a great observation, Sarah. Moses 1 gives us essential context before diving into the Creation. It addresses profound questions like who God is, who we are, and what His great work really means for us.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly. What strikes me is how the Lord immediately focuses on Moses' true identity. In Moses 1:4, He says, 'And thou art my son; wherefore look and I will show thee the workmanship of mine hands.' How does that set the tone?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It establishes Moses' divine worth right away. Then in verse 6, the Lord adds, 'Thou art in the similitude of mine Only Begotten.' This isn't just flattery—it's a declaration of our eternal potential as children of God.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's powerful. But then Satan shows up in verse 12 with a very different message: 'Moses, son of man, worship me.' It's such a stark contrast. What's fascinating is how this plays out differently from God's perspective versus Satan's.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, God affirms our nobility and likeness to His Son, while Satan tries to reduce us to something lesser, like 'son of man' without the divine context. President Nelson taught that the first thing the Lord would help us understand is our true identity, because Satan works so hard to confuse it.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I hadn't thought of it quite that way. So this pattern of identity declaration appears right at the start. How did Moses respond when Satan tempted him?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Moses remembered his experience with God. In verses 13-15, he says, 'I am a son of God, in the similitude of his Only Begotten,' and commands Satan to depart. It's a model for us—relying on what God has revealed about who we are.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's a profound realization. Notice how Satan tempts with counterfeits, mimicking God's power but without the truth. What helped Moses overcome him completely?

script.speaker: David
script.text: In verses 20-22 and 26, Moses calls upon God, and the Lord rebukes Satan. It shows that even after powerful spiritual experiences, we need the Lord's help to resist. This connects so meaningfully to our own temptations today.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I'm intrigued by that. After this, Moses asks in verse 30, 'Tell me ... why these things are so.' The Lord's response in verses 31-39 is stunning about His work and glory.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Absolutely. Verse 39 declares, 'For behold, this is my work and my glory—to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.' Immortality comes through the Resurrection, but eternal life is exaltation, made possible by Jesus Christ.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: What a beautiful purpose. Now, Abraham 3 builds on this with a vision of our premortal existence. Verses 22-28 describe spirits before the world was. How does that tie back to Moses' experience?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It's remarkable continuity. Abraham sees the intelligences organized before the earth was formed. Verse 23 says, 'God saw these souls that they were good, and he stood in the midst of them.' This mirrors God's affirmation to Moses.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's deepening my understanding. Verse 25 talks about us coming to earth to be proven: 'We will prove them herewith, to see if they will do all things whatsoever the Lord their God shall command them.' Our premortal choices led here.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And verse 27 highlights the Savior's role: 'These I will make my rulers; for he stood among those that were spirits.' Jesus was chosen premortally to lead and redeem us, fulfilling God's work from Moses 1:39.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: What many don't realize is how these revelations came through Joseph Smith as an inspired translation and Abraham's record. That historical context illuminates why we have this fuller picture now.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Precisely. The book of Moses revises Genesis to provide this foundation, showing prophetic continuity from ancient times through modern revelation. It transforms how we see the entire Old Testament.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Here's what I find meaningful—these truths about our divine identity and premortal life. President Nelson said the way we think about who we are affects every decision. How can we apply that?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Consider making a list of choices you make because you're a child of God first, before other labels. It helps resist Satan's counterfeits, just like Moses did. Knowing we lived as spirits motivates us to prove faithful.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's exactly right. Imagine looking in the mirror and declaring, as God did to Moses, 'I am a child of God.' It changes how we treat ourselves and others.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And it points to Christ, who makes eternal life possible. These patterns across dispensations remind us of our place in God's plan.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, this has been so enlightening. As we close, I invite everyone to ponder these verses this week—study Moses 1 and Abraham 3, reflect on your divine destiny, and let it guide your choices.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Great invitation, Sarah. Knowing who we are truly empowers us to fulfill our purpose on earth.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Thanks for joining us. Until next time!
